description: From gab +‎ -le. Cognate with Saterland Frisian gabbelje (“to mock”), Dutch gabbelen (“to chatter, babble”), German Low German gabbeln (“to mock”).

examples: a lot of gabble from witnesses

verbs.description: gabble (third-person singular simple present gabbles, present participle gabbling, simple past and past participle gabbled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To talk fast, idly, foolishly, or without meaning.
examples: Does she regard him simply as a workman come to do a job for her, someone whom she need never lay eyes on again; or is she gabbling to hide discomfiture?

entries.meaning: To utter inarticulate sounds with rapidity.
